utterances: Funky.
It can mean artsy and fun, or kind of gross, or all of the above.
The word comes up a lot when you ask about the market and its history.
They wanted it funky.
They wanted fresh produce.
They wanted the history.
They wanted it all.
And they got it.
That's Michael Yaeger, the so-called mayor of the market.
He's a historian and a hardcore preservationist.
He writes about the market and sells his wife's watercolors in a booth that's got a special place in market history.

When the farmers would bring their horse-drawn wagons full of produce here, they'd put their horses in this stable in front of our store, up these ramps, and then check in here at The Wagon Master(ph) and then go out to sell their produce.
Cheap strawberries, a dollar a box.
(Soundbite of tapping)
A dollar a box, strawberries.
Come on.
Originally, the market was only for local produce.
Today, produce is trucked in from all over - and musicians, craftspeople and specialty retailers are also part of the mix.
And of course there's the guys who throw fish; hard not to mention them.
(Soundbite of fish sellers)
And working quietly behind those guys, Don Kuzaro Jr. of Don and Joe's Meats.
Mr. DON KUZARO JR. (Don and Joe's Meats): Anything else today?
I never really understood why people like to have their food thrown, but it works for my neighbors.
Kuzaro's family has been in the market since 1924.
He says if you want to work there, you have to like people.
And it doesn't hurt to have a butcher's sense of humor.
Mr.
KUZARO JR.: This morning I was working really fast.
But when I was making hamburger, I kind of backed into the grinder, got a little behind in my work.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Kuzaro says the market is like a circus - hectic, unpredictable.
Rich people, poor people and everyone in between come in to shop every day.
And it doesn't just feel old-fashioned - the buildings are old, and they're all managed by Preservation and Development Authority, or PDA, right downstairs from Don and Joe's.
And they also believe in reincarnation?
Think about taxes on cigarettes and alcohol.
Blanke points back to the period after the American Revolution when Alexander Hamilton cited fiscal and health justifications for taxing whiskey.
In the case to be heard today, the beverage industry seeks to invalidate Philadelphia's soda tax.
One of the industry's legal arguments is that the city's tax on beverages conflicts with Pennsylvania's state sales tax.
And outside the courtroom, the industry makes the case that the soda tax hurts small businesses.
Here's Anthony Campisi of the Ax the Philly Bev Tax coalition.
I think that this tax has been an economic disaster for Philadelphia.
Campisi says some residents of Philadelphia now go to the suburbs to shop to avoid the higher prices.
So he says it's not clear whether overall people have cut back on sweetened drinks.
Allison Aubrey, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF MOSS OF AURA'S ""DIM"")
Budweiser, the king of beers, and if you're watching a game on TV, it's pretty often king of commercials too.
So why not king of Web?
The new Internet channel called Bud TV caught the attention of critic Andrew Wallenstein.
(Soundbite of Budweiser commercial)
Unidentified Man #1: Yo!
Yo, pick up the phone.
Unidentified Man #2: Hello.
Unidentified Man #1: Wazup!
Unidentified Man #1: Wazup!
Blahhh.
Remember when that catch phrase just wouldn't die a few years ago?
Blame Budweiser, which made it the rallying cry of some of its seemingly endless supply of commercials.
Maybe you saw a recent addition to the canon, featuring a young couple who come upon a hitchhiker while driving along a darkened highway.
(Soundbite of Budweiser commercial)
Unidentified Woman #1: What are you doing?
Unidentified Man #3: Should we pick him up?
He has Bud Light.
Unidentified Woman #1: He has an ax!
Unidentified Man #3: But he has Bud Light.
Unidentified Woman #1: And an ax!
Now, I don't know about you.
But I've seen so many of these goofy beer ads that I've become immune to their charms.
And Budweiser might be thinking the same thing, given its new venture.
This week the company kicked off an online only entertainment channel it calls Bud TV, which you can access at www.bud.tv.
It's a collection of many different mini shows, usually about five minutes each from a bunch of different genres.
There's a sci-fi action show, a ""Daily Show""-style mock newscast.
Several programs allow users to contribute their own homemade video, and just lots and lots of comedy.
Here's one with a title that could use some explaining.
It's called ""Replaced by a Chimp.
(Soundbite of ""Replaced by a Chimp"")
Unidentified Man #4: He's dedicated.
Unidentified Man #5: That's a hell of a presentation.
Unidentified Man #4: He's focused.
Unidentified Woman #2: I am so happy I found you.
Unidentified Man #4: He's a chimp.
And now he just might have your job.
Okay, that's kind of funny.
I would love to see a chimpanzee do my job.
Overall, Bud TV is off to a good start, with a compelling mix of off-kilter comedy.
But right about now you might be asking yourself, what on Earth does all this have to do with selling beer?
Think about it.
Commercials are an endangered species.
More and more homes are equipped with ad-skipping digital video recorders like Tivo.
Plus, the young male audience Budweiser targets spends increasing amounts of time on the Web at sites like You Tube.
So that makes some sense.
Right?
But the strange thing about Bud TV is it hardly ever references Budweiser.
You might see a bottle of beer pop up in a scene or two, but the brand barely registers.
It makes you wonder, what's the point of this whole enterprise if not to sell beer?
And that's the audacity of the grand experiment that is Bud TV.

Their hope is that if you become a fan of this programming mix, just the positive association with a Budweiser-branded channel is enough to parch your throat next time you're walking down 7-Eleven's beverage aisle.
Hasn't worked for me yet.
But who's to say that won't work just as well as a direct pitch to other consumers?
Now, imagine if this concept catches on with other brands.
Why should marketers bother with commercials or product placement on existing channels when they could be a channel themselves?
Who knows?
I could see a day when a young-skewing network like, say, Comedy Central, will get competition for ratings from the same company that once contributed to its ad revenues.
Bud TV may not seem like a revelation yet.
But watching it, I found it hard to shake the notion that it could be a revolution, redefining the connection between advertisers and consumers.
Critic Andrew Wallenstein is an editor at the Hollywood Reporter.
For President Bush, delivering the State of the Union address is followed by another tradition the day after: selling it.
This morning the President was in Wilmington, Delaware, trying to get public support for his energy proposals.
I'm joined now by NPR White House correspondent Don Gonyea.
And Don, what was the president's sales pitch this morning?
Well you know what he's trying to do?
He's trying to gain some successes as part of a domestic agenda even though so much of the focus is on all of the turmoil in Iraq.
And in the speech last night he talked about energy and the need for the U.S.
to reduce its dependence on foreign supplies of oil.
So today he was in Delaware.
He was at a DuPont facility in Wilmington.
And he was talking about that, that very topic.
Not in a big prepared speech.
Just making comments on it.
But it's part of kind of focusing the attention on individual elements of the speech.
